title: Poor diagnostics for missing unwrap caused by `Result::contains`

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: D-confusing
labels.description: Confusing diagnostic error that should be reworked

body:
Given the following code: [Playground](https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=nightly&mode=debug&edition=2021&gist=ba16f8254d21d4c3d9b389f320ec57bb)

```rust
pub fn foo(hs: &Mutex<HashSet<u8>>) -> bool {
    hs.lock().contains(&42)
}
```

The current output is:

```
error[E0658]: use of unstable library feature 'option_result_contains'
 --> contains.rs:5:15
  |
5 |     hs.lock().contains(&42)
  |               ^^^^^^^^
  |
  = note: see issue #62358 <https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/62358> for more information
  = help: add `#![feature(option_result_contains)]` to the crate attributes to enable

error[E0277]: can't compare `{integer}` with `MutexGuard<'_, HashSet<u8>>`
    --> contains.rs:5:24
     |
5    |     hs.lock().contains(&42)
     |               -------- ^^^ no implementation for `{integer} == MutexGuard<'_, HashSet<u8>>`
     |               |
     |               required by a bound introduced by this call
     |
     = help: the trait `PartialEq<MutexGuard<'_, HashSet<u8>>>` is not implemented for `{integer}`
note: required by a bound in `Result::<T, E>::contains`

```

This is a bit confusing error, epecially for a beginners. If not for the existence of the `option_result_contains` feature (https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/62358), the error would look something like:

```
error[E0599]: no method named `foo` found for enum `Result` in the current scope
 --> contains.rs:5:15
  |
5 |     hs.lock().foo(&42)
  |               ^^^ method not found in `Result<MutexGuard<'_, HashSet<u8>>, PoisonError<MutexGuard<'_, HashSet<u8>>>>`
```

which is more straightforward. Would be nice for the "missing-feature" error to have a note that it actually tried calling `contains` directly on `Result`, as that's non-obvious.

(When that feature gets stabilized, the resulting error is still confusing IMO (especially for somebody not aware of existence of `Result::contains` IMO). But I guess resolving that is in scope of https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/62358)
